facts.text: On February 9, 1960, respondent's godown was searched and 178 Mds. of paddy found stored without licence.
Respondent pleaded paddy was for consumption of his 15 family members and 40 Mds. belonged to Lalito Singh.

Sub Divisional Magistrate, Bishenpur disbelieved family consumption plea, believed Lalito Singh's claim for 40 Mds., released it, presumed rest under cl.3(2) attracted cl.3(1), convicted under s.7 Essential Commodities Act, fined Rs.500 or 3 months RI, no forfeiture.
Sessions Judge, Manipur dismissed appeal, confirmed conviction and sentence.

Judicial Commissioner, Manipur allowed revision on Dec 2, 1961, set aside conviction following prior judgment in revisions 7,11,13/1961 dated June 5, 1961 holding cl.3(2) presumption does not deem person a dealer under cl.3(1).
Manipur Administration filed appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Construction of cl.3(2) of Manipur Foodgrains Dealers Licensing Order, 1958: Does presumption of storing 100+ maunds for sale deem the person a 'dealer' carrying on business under cl.3(1), attracting s.7 Essential Commodities Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Cl.3(2) deeming provision creates fiction that storage of 100+ maunds is for sale, drawn for purpose of cl.3(1); sufficient to prove dealer status and liability under s.7; view of Judicial Commissioner misconstructs clause.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Cl.3(2), Cl.3(1) of Manipur Foodgrains Dealers Licensing Order, 1958

petitioner_arguments.text: Strict construction of penal clause requires maximum legitimate fiction from deeming provision; limiting presumption defeats purpose.

respondent_arguments.text: Presumption under cl.3(2) only that storage is for sale, not that it constitutes 'business' of dealer under cl.2(a) and cl.3(1); prosecution must prove business element (continuity) separately.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Cl.2(a), Cl.3(1), Cl.3(2) of Manipur Foodgrains Dealers Licensing Order, 1958

court_reasoning.text: Cl.3 is penal, strictly construed. Dealer under cl.2(a) requires 'business' of purchase/sale/storage for sale of 100+ maunds, implying continuity, not single transaction. Forms in Order support this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Business' postulates continuity of transactions; single storage insufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.3(2) raises rebuttable presumption only that storage of 100+ maunds is 'for purpose of sale'; does not cover 'business' element essential for cl.3(1). Prosecution must prove business by other evidence (e.g., multiple instances).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption limited; reference to cl.3(1) does not widen it to include business.

court_reasoning.text: Clause worded deliberately for limited presumption to exclude cultivators with occasional large possession/sale. Cannot add words to provision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial Commissioner correct; conviction not sustainable.

holdings.text: Presumption under cl.3(2) deems storage for sale but not 'business'; prosecution must independently prove business element for dealer status under cl.3(1) and s.7 liability.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishes contravention of Order; applied if unlicensed dealer business proven

statutes_cited.name: Manipur Foodgrains Dealers Licensing Order, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines dealer requiring business; licensing requirement; presumption on storage; interpreted narrowly

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by Manipur Administration, upheld Judicial Commissioner's order of acquittal setting aside conviction and sentence under s.7 Essential Commodities Act.

key_quotes.text: "any person who stores any foodgrains in quantity of one hundred maunds or more at any one time shall, unless the contrary is proved, be deemed to store the foodgrains for the purpose of sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exact text of cl.3(2) central to construction

key_quotes.text: "the presumption would still be that the store is made for the purpose of sale, and that presumption would be drawn for the purpose of cl. 3(1). That is the only effect"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is not a single, casual or solitary transaction of sale, purchase or storage that would make a person a dealer."
key_quotes.speaker: court
